results.title: Computers in engineering
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Living with Computers”.
Martin Jones, a civil engineer, talks about the use of computers in engineering - a paper presented to the Junior World Computer Congress, Melbourne, October 1980.

results.title: Beginning silk screening on fabric (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brenton Holmes, Open College of Further Education (S. Aust.) and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This program demonstrates the basic procedures for silk-screening on to fabric using paper stencils. Building a frame, attaching the silk, preparing stencils and making a two-colour print are shown

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 36]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various recreational activities in the life of the Anderson family, including water skiing, riding speed boats on a lake, a trip to the snow, visiting the Royal Melbourne Show, birthday parties, swimming at a local pool, and a Christmas morning.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 skimming stones at the river
00:01:15:00 picnic lunch, eating sausages in bread
00:03:55:00 an ANSETT plane at a country airport
00:07:40:00 water skiing on a large lake
00:08:25:00 groups of people on the shores of the lake
00:09:46:00 man with binoculars
00:10:24:00 kids eating ice creams
00:11:02:00 sign for ‘Water Ski Spectacular: The Fastest Show on Water’
00:11:18:00 the three boys at a table set with birthday cake and party cups
00:15:04:00 on a speedboat on the lake
00:18:47:00 another birthday party with balloons and cake
00:18:56:00 double-layer sponge cake on a rotating tray (lazy Susan)
00:21:47:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:22:33:00 trip to the snow
00:23:18:00 kids learning to ski
00:25:00:00 siblings in matching outfits holding hands at the Royal Show
00:25:12:00 Showbags stall
00:25:17:00 on the Racing Speedboats ride
00:26:15:00 the Kiddies Ferris Wheel
00:26:25:00 the Merry-Go-Round with the older girls holding the boys on
00:27:08:00 on the Speed Car ride
00:27:57:00 girl with fairy floss in front of the fairy floss stand and then thoroughly enjoying it
00:28:13:00 sign for ‘Delicious Flavoured Milk’
00:29:29:00 the Mad Mouse ride
00:30:00:00 Christmas morning with a pile of presents under the tree and the kids in their pyjamas
00:31:25:00 in the backyard riding new bikes and race car toys
00:33:15:00 playing at the local pool with an inflatable boat
00:37:34:00 a large group of kids lined up for a bike race
00:38:37:00 group of girls on the trampoline
00:39:04:00 cake with a ballerina and ‘Happy Birthday to Denise’ written on top
00:39:28:00 blowing party horns

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 34]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film begins with scenes of kids’ birthday parties, horse riding and sports in Ballarat. The family then make a road trip to South Australia, featuring city streets in Adelaide, a visit to an amusement park and a wildlife sanctuary, and more horse riding.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 kids’ athletics day
00:01:16:00 girl dismounting a horse from the back of the saddle
00:02:05:00 horse-riding at an equestrian club
00:07:13:00 a group of kids having fun on a trampoline
00:07:30:00 riding a horse in the backyard
00:08:05:00 kids seated around a table eating cake
00:08:50:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:10:24:00 playing musical chairs
00:12:01:00 kids’ footy (AFL football) match
00:14:01:00 a nun cheering from the sidelines
00:16:05:00 parents watching from the sidelines
00:18:31:00 man riding a horse down a suburban street
00:20:45:00 on a road trip, at the border of South Australia
00:21:59:00 fish and chips on the bonnet of the car
00:23:25:00 busy Adelaide street with Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society building in the background
00:24:09:00 in a department store
00:24:53:00 the kids on a Ferris Wheel and other carnival rides
00:25:50:00 trained seals doing tricks
00:28:00:00 dolphins jumping through rings
00:29:42:00 group family shot at a wildlife sanctuary
00:30:56:00 kids patting a kangaroo
00:32:00:00 kids walking down the steps of an ANSETT plane
00:33:12:00 one of the kids on a tire swing
00:34:18:00 cowboy on a horse
00:34:52:00 paddling around in kayaks on a lake
00:36:23:00 on a boat cruising down the river
00:37:08:00 old steam trains in a yard
00:37:15:00 city streets including trams
00:37:58:00 boys running down train tracks
00:39:01:00 arriving home and pulling suitcases out of the boot of the car

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows a trip to Adelaide and regional South Australia, including views of the city streets, neon signs, animals, trees and flowers in the countryside, and a horse-drawn tram on the coast, probably at Victor Harbor.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:44:00 aerial view over city streets
00:0:57:00 view of busy street with large ‘Ezy’s’ sign
00:02:34:00 Port Adelaide ship
00:03:41:00 Marie holding a koala
00:04:47:00 neon signs at night
00:06:02:00 in a citrus orchard
00:08:18:00 people on a horse-drawn tram, likely at Victor Harbor

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 30]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows life in Ballarat and regional Victoria in the 1950s, including kids’ birthdays, picnics in the park and holidays at the beach. The film is mainly in colour and the last few minutes are in black and white.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 cute baby playing a toy piano
00:01:40:00 a kid’s birthday party
00:03:22:00 kids playing in a band, including banjo, piano accordion, and guitar
00:04:00:00 playing footy in the front yard of a suburban house
00:05:36:00 title card ‘Wayne 1 Year’ superimposed over a baby with a cake
00:06:40:00 baby in a bath tub in the garden
00:08:22:00 picnic at a park with some excellent shots of a 1950s car
00:10:13:00 the family going on ‘Pad-o-lo’ paddle catamarans
00:12:13:00 Marie and friend eating in the car at a park picnic
00:14:15:00 two men in bathers in a sand bag competition
00:16:04:00 nice shot of Marie on the beach in a lovely printed dress and colourful towel over her head
00:16:35:00 John in a suit on a motorbike
00:21:05:00 local boys playing a game of rugby
00:21:28:00 film changes to black and white for a picnic in the park

Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows life in Ballarat and regional Victoria in the 1950s, including kids’ birthdays, picnics in the park and holidays at the beach. The film is mainly in colour and the last few minutes are in black and white.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 cute baby playing a toy piano
00:01:40:00 a kid’s birthday party
00:03:22:00 kids playing in a band, including banjo, piano accordion, and guitar
00:04:00:00 playing footy in the front yard of a suburban house
00:05:36:00 title card ‘Wayne 1 Year’ superimposed over a baby with a cake
00:06:40:00 baby in a bath tub in the garden
00:08:22:00 picnic at a park with some excellent shots of a 1950s car
00:10:13:00 the family going on ‘Pad-o-lo’ paddle catamarans
00:12:13:00 Marie and friend eating in the car at a park picnic
00:14:15:00 two men in bathers in a sand bag competition
00:16:04:00 nice shot of Marie on the beach in a lovely printed dress and colourful towel over her head
00:16:35:00 John in a suit on a motorbike
00:21:05:00 local boys playing a game of rugby
00:21:28:00 film changes to black and white for a picnic in the park

group.title: [John Anderson Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 7x 16mm film assorted newsreels and home movie. Can of 9.5mm assorted smaller reels. Focus on Ballarat. Family collection by filmmaker John (Jack) Anderson (dec.)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows the wedding of John and Marie’s daughter Sharon to Graeme on 15 January 1977, featuring some great 70s fashion.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 title card ‘Graeme & Sharon, St Patrick’s Cathedral, 15-1-77’
00:00:18:00 Marie walking out of the house in a floor-length dress
00:00:49:00 Sharon in her wedding dress leaving the house and getting into the red car
00:02:32:00 some great 70s fashion amongst the guests
00:03:18:00 the married couple being pelted with confetti by her siblings and friends at the church gate
00:04:10:00 Sharon being carried across the lawn
00:04:35:00 on a river cruise to the reception
00:05:35:00 the married couple cutting the cake
00:06:00:00 Sharon and her brothers on the dance floor

results.title: The Brown dressing gown
results.brief_description: Patric fondly remembers his social worker Julie Wilson who helped him come out of his cocoon and discard his brown dressing gown. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and The Deafness Foundation.

results.title: What's the name of that place you come from nan?
results.creator_credit: Rita Hinekauia Morrison and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Rita comes from a mixed cultural background but her strongest connection is with the Maori side of her family. She shares her memories and family history in this digital story so that her Maori heritage can be preserved through future generations.

results.title: A Place called Gapuwiyak
results.creator_credit: Nicole La Gerche and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: This is Nicole’s story of her experiences living in East Arnhem, of being adopted into and accepted by the Wunungmurra family and the Yolngu community.
